hints.content:
The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.

We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!

The *fraction bar* has a shaded length of $3$ halves.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-sixth unit. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. The first three parts are shaded. The shaded parts are between 0 and three-halves on the number line.

hints.content:
Each *half* has $5$ equal pieces, with $4$ pieces shaded on the number line.

[[☃ image 1]]

The shaded length on the number line represents $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of $3$ halves.

options.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with minor tick marks every one-tenth unit and major tick marks every one-half unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-half, one, three-halves, and 2. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the three-halves tick mark. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 20 equal parts. The first 4 parts, parts 6 through 9, and parts 11 through 14 are shaded in dark green. The first 4 dark green parts are between 0 and the fourth tick mark after 0, the next 4 dark green parts are between one-half and the fourth tick mark after one-half, and the last 4 dark green parts are between 1 and the fourth tick mark after 1. The fifth, tenth, and fifteenth parts are shaded in light green. The first light green part is between the fourth  tick mark after 0 and the one-half tick mark, the next light green part is between the fourth tick mark after one-half and the 1 tick mark, and the last light green part is  between the fourth tick mark after  1 and the three-halves tick mark.  There are 3 curved brackets above the fraction bar. Each curved bracket is labeled one-half. First curved bracket is above the first through fifth shaded parts, second curved bracket is above sixth through tenth shaded parts, and third curved bracket  is above eleventh through fifteenth shaded parts.

hints.content: We can represent the shaded length with the description $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of $\dfrac{3}{2}$.
